2 hours ago, KocLobster said:

How does that work exactly? If they have the exact same parts, how do they not have essentially the exact same performance? The performance would be the same, it's just the price would be a lot higher for that in a laptop than in a desktop.

Because they don't have the exact same parts! The marketing departments at Intel, AMD, and nVidia will freely give similar brand names and model numbers to some very different components in laptops and desktops. For example a GTX 960M is a significantly weaker graphics chip than a GTX 960, in fact the 960M is very similar to the desktop 750 Ti.

So you need to do your research to know what performance a laptop will actually get.
